titleStmt.title:
Mrs. Pilkington having heard that Dean Swift had
received a Paper Book from th Earl of Orrery, and
a Silver Standish from Dr. Delany, sent the Dean
an Eagle's Quill, with the following lines on the
occasion.

publicationStmt.p: Distributed by Digital Scholarship Services at Lafayette College

lg.l: Shall then my kindred all my glory claim,
And boldly rob me of eternal fame?
To ev'ry art my gen'rous aid I lend,
To music, painting, poetry, a friend.
·Quills of the harpsichord.When fix'd to strike the sweetly warbling wire.
I to the faithful canvas have consign'd
Each bright idea of the painter's mind;
Behold from Raphael's sky-dipt pencils rise
Such heav'nly scenes as charm the gazer's eyes.
O let me now aspire to higher praise!
Ambitious to transcribe your deathless lays:
Nor thou, immortal bard! my aid refuse,
Accept me as the servant of your muse;
Then shall the world my wond'rous worth declare,

And all mankind your matchless pen revere.·The Dean in a letter to Mrs. Pilkington says, “I never saw better verses in their kind than those you have pleased to make upon me; of which opinion are some particular friends of genius and taste to whom I ventured to communicate them. I can only assure you, that I value your present as much as either of the others, only you must permit it to be turned into a pen; which office I will perform with my own hand, and never permit any other to use it.”.
